objects.name: EKANS  Ransomware
objects.description:
EKANS Ransomware is written in GoLang, upon infection, revelvant files are overwritten with encrypted data. Each file has a string of EKANS (Snake backwards) in the end of the file.

The ransomware uses aAES-256 and RSA-2048 for encryption. Like many ransomwares the malware excludes critical system files from encryption, and even attempts to compromise network resources. Snake also has the capability of terminating numerous process related with SCADA platforms and enterprise enviorments.

If successful the ransom note will be written to "C:\Users\Public\Desktop\Fix-Your-Files.txt"

References:
https://twitter.com/VK_Intel/status/1215196590165647360
https://www.carbonblack.com/2020/01/27/threat-analysis-unit-tau-threat-intelligence-notification-snake-ransomware/
https://insights.sei.cmu.edu/cert/2020/03/snake-ransomware-analysis-updates.html
https://nakedsecurity.sophos.com/2020/01/13/snake-alert-this-ransomware-is-not-a-game/
https://www.dragos.com/blog/industry-news/ekans-ransomware-and-ics-operations/

objects.name: EKANS
objects.description: Ekans, also known as Snake, is a targeted ransomware family written in the Go programming language. Ekans leverages a mix of symmetric and asymmetric cryptography for the encryption and decryption of targeted files on the victim. Like many ransomware malware families, Ekans attempts to also encrypt resources connected to the victim machine via the network.
